stream_context.summary: Kaze integrates Biobak’s huge visual overhaul of “Wario’s Wildlife World,” re-imports and fixes new object/animation assets, and hunts down engine bugs while outlining plans for multiplayer, monthly public testing, and an animation-streaming system.

development_findings.summary: Multiplayer groundwork finished this week (net-code prep, stability and performance tweaks) and will be built into the main ROM, not a separate build.
Screen transitions now use Lilaa’s radius-scaling code for a side-wipe effect instead of instant pop-in.
development_findings.quote: Oh, yeah, I didn’t mention that, but we have smoother transitions now – it pops in from the side all the way instead of instantly being there.

development_findings.summary: Monthly course testing is returning: each month one standalone-ROM level will be sent to a single external tester to validate gameplay.
development_findings.quote: I think we’re gonna bring back monthly course testing, where a player will just get to test one course at a time.

development_findings.summary: Massive zoo remodel by Biobak: new textures, benches, bushes, teddy bear, signage, lighting, zip-lines, chain-chomp pen, aquarium décor, etc. Kaze fixes UV maps, fog, and culling.
New animation-streaming system loads individual frames at runtime, removing length limits (used for Mario shuffle dance).
development_findings.quote: We’re basically using a new technique where instead of loading the entire animation at once, we’re loading individual frames into memory – as long as there’s cart space, you can just keep going.

development_findings.summary: Several objects re-authored: tire swing, chain-chomp gate, wooden boat, blooper, cheep-cheep, broken table. Texture counts reduced, culling disabled, shading added, random scaling code updated.
Bug fix: behaviour scripts were zeroing a pointer after object-field layout change (0x3D → 0x40), preventing NPC dialogue and causing crashes; Kaze patched field and stack handling.
development_findings.quote: The current behavior comment is being set to zero... setting that value might cause the behavior script pointer to become invalid – that explains the crash.

development_findings.summary: Performance/compatibility notes: avoid ENV-color-alpha and culling flags in Fast64; combine textures only when it doesn’t force larger atlas; shade-color now preferred for world lighting.
Aquarium glass and water need reflective material or fingerprint decal; water fog/scrolling fixed; manta splines may need adjustment.
Antarctic plane minigame feedback logged: consider obstacle explosions, neutral zone widen, but timer increase resisted pending tester data.
RTYI engine and hack will be fully open source.
development_findings.quote: Yeah, the engine will be completely open source. The entire hack here will be open source.

development_findings.summary: Design philosophy: keep risk and possible frustration; avoid modern ‘frustration-minimised’ design.
development_findings.quote: I think modern video games are just frustration minimised... I try not to do that.

context_findings.summary: Kaze refuses exhaustive regression testing after every change; prefers quick fixes based on memory to save time.
context_findings.quote: Checking the entire game would have taken longer than just fixing it.

context_findings.summary: He values authenticity over PR: declines charity-video trends and calls fans ‘people,’ rejecting heavy parasocial framing.
context_findings.quote: I don’t really care about charity, so I’m not even going to make a video pretending about it.

context_findings.summary: Work environment: extreme heat, Canada Day; replaced failing mouse mid-stream (‘pipelining mice’ spare-mouse strategy).
context_findings.quote: I always have one in store, so when one breaks I instantly have a new one – I call this pipelining mice.

context_findings.summary: Philosophy on game difficulty: welcomes players getting stuck; sees honest feedback (‘your level is shit’) as valuable.
context_findings.quote: If your level is shit and people tell you it’s shit, you should still be happy – that’s the most useful thing you can get.

biobak.summary: Delivered large redo of Wario’s Wildlife World: new textures, lighting, benches, bushes, aquarium props, signs, trophy room, Wario’s office décor.
Optimised models by merging materials, lowering vertex counts, updating collision, but sometimes used ENV-color-alpha causing fog mismatch.

zeina.summary: Created new 12×12 transparent butt-print texture for ground-pound marks; mirrored correctly.
Animating Mario shuffle dance; using Yoshi Milkman + Zeina IK rig; learned foot-shuffle.
zeina.quote: I spent half the day yesterday learning how to foot shuffle and I almost got it right.

key_stories.title: Zoo Overhaul Day
key_stories.summary: Biobak ships a huge visual rework of the zoo level; Kaze live-reviews, fixes UV seams, fog, and snapping, then recompiles to see the level come alive.
key_stories.challenge: Existing zoo looked flat and dated; needed cohesive theme and performance-friendly textures.
key_stories.process: Biobak remodelled assets; Kaze imported, spotted UV and fog issues, adjusted walls, disabled culling, re-exported.
key_stories.outcome: Level now ‘looks so much more alive’; collision and glass reflections still on task list.
key_stories.key_quote: The level looks so much more alive now.

key_stories.title: Dialogue Crash Hunt
key_stories.summary: A sudden inability to talk to zoo penguins crashes the game. Kaze debugs MIPS assembly live to trace a field-offset regression.
key_stories.challenge: Behaviour script pointer became zero, crashing on interaction.
key_stories.process: Single-step through clear_object_condition, identify object field 0x3D overwrite, move ‘damage’ field to 0x40.
key_stories.outcome: Fix restores NPC interaction and prevents further crashes.
key_stories.key_quote: We have found the issue – setting that value might cause the behavior script pointer to become invalid.

key_stories.title: Animation Streaming Breakthrough
key_stories.summary: Desire for longer, memory-heavy animations (Mario dance) prompts a new engine feature.
key_stories.challenge: Traditional SM64 loads entire animation into RAM, limiting length.
key_stories.process: Implement per-frame streaming into memory; inform Zeina that dances can now be arbitrarily long.
key_stories.outcome: Team free to create lengthy, high-quality cut-scene animations without memory wall.
key_stories.key_quote: You can make it as long as you want – we’re loading individual frames of the animation.

key_stories.title: Mouse Pipeline
key_stories.summary: Kaze’s mouse fails mid-stream; he hot-swaps to a $10 spare, illustrating his ‘pipelining mice’ habit.
key_stories.challenge: Input device randomly stops right-clicking, stalling Blender fixes.
key_stories.process: Diagnose mouse vs. Blender, retrieve packaged spare, plug in, resume work.
key_stories.outcome: Stream continues; Kaze orders another cheap backup.
key_stories.key_quote: I always have one in store… I call this pipelining mice.
